body: I enjoy the updates, they're a big part of what kept me coming back to the game year after year and still having things to do. I don't think they took anything away from what makes Minecraft what it is.
body_html: I enjoy the updates, they're a big part of what kept me coming back to the game year after year and still having things to do. I don't think they took anything away from what makes Minecraft what it is.

body:
On its own, the updates are very good. But they're focusing on all the wrong things. Minecraft used to be about building a bunch of stuff, optionally with a few monsters to make it harder, and that's how it was played. Now the focus is almost exclusively on survival and fantasy gaming, with the updates being all about powerups, combat, weird mobs and structures, mechanics, etc. And that's how everyone plays it now. And yes it does take away from what it is, many of the new updates change the whole core mechanics that had been so iconic and in place for years. It's impossible to enjoy it the same way it had been for so long.

I think it initially started with Beta 1.7/1.8 when Jeb took over, but back then at least it was just some controversial decisions and not completely ridding the original genre. But the updates since 1.9 have upped this to the tenth power. After the Adventure update (Beta 1.8) many people didn't like how things had changed directions, but looking back Infdev-b1.7.3 vs b1.8-1.7.10 actually have a lot more more in common with each other than they do with current Minecraft! They even felt the need to change all the textures and models because it's just not the same game anymore.

On a brighter note, the cave update is the first in forever that looks like it might actually bring something to the building and mining part, so that's good. But it doesn't matter to me, since I've never adapted to 1.9+.
body_html:
On its own, the updates are very good. But they're focusing on all the wrong things. Minecraft used to be about building a bunch of stuff, optionally with a few monsters to make it harder, and that's how it was played. Now the focus is almost exclusively on survival and fantasy gaming, with the updates being all about powerups, combat, weird mobs and structures, mechanics, etc. And that's how everyone plays it now. And yes it does take away from what it is, many of the new updates change the whole core mechanics that had been so iconic and in place for years. It's impossible to enjoy it the same way it had been for so long.

I think it initially started with Beta 1.7/1.8 when Jeb took over, but back then at least it was just some controversial decisions and not completely ridding the original genre. But the updates since 1.9 have upped this to the tenth power. After the Adventure update (Beta 1.8) many people didn't like how things had changed directions, but looking back Infdev-b1.7.3 vs b1.8-1.7.10 actually have a lot more more in common with each other than they do with current Minecraft! They even felt the need to change all the textures and models because it's just not the same game anymore.

On a brighter note, the cave update is the first in forever that looks like it might actually bring something to the building and mining part, so that's good. But it doesn't matter to me, since I've never adapted to 1.9+.

Now the focus is almost exclusively on survival and fantasy gaming, with the updates being all about powerups, combat, weird mobs and structures, mechanics, etc. And that's how everyone plays it now. It's impossible to enjoy it the same way it had been for so long.

Now the focus is almost exclusively on survival and fantasy gaming, with the updates being all about powerups, combat, weird mobs and structures, mechanics, etc. And that's how everyone plays it now. And yes it does take away from what it is, many of the new updates change the whole core mechanics that had been so iconic and in place for years. It's impossible to enjoy it the same way it had been for so long.

I think it initially started with Beta 1.7/1.8 when Jeb took over, but back then at least it was just some controversial decisions and not completely ridding the original genre. But the updates since 1.9 have upped this to the tenth power. After the Adventure update (Beta 1.8) many people didn't like how things had changed directions, but looking back Infdev-b1.7.3 vs b1.8-1.7.10 actually have a lot more more in common with each other than they do with current Minecraft! body: What do you miss being able to do that you can't now? 1.7 beta is about where I got into it, so maybe some nostalgia for older versions is lost on me, but what I loved about having a little world where I build my things and explore is still there, except with more materials to choose from, more places to explore and different mobs to make it interesting. I agree that not all updates were good or focused on the right thing - I didn't like the direction the texture pack took either, the underground is in a sorry state and even terrain generation could really have been made more interesting by now, but generally I found it pretty easy to just not bother with the things I don't care about. I get that a lot specifics on how things are done changed, but you can still play it as a game where you build stuff + monsters.
body_html: What do you miss being able to do that you can't now? 1.7 beta is about where I got into it, so maybe some nostalgia for older versions is lost on me, but what I loved about having a little world where I build my things and explore is still there, except with more materials to choose from, more places to explore and different mobs to make it interesting. I agree that not all updates were good or focused on the right thing - I didn't like the direction the texture pack took either, the underground is in a sorry state and even terrain generation could really have been made more interesting by now, but generally I found it pretty easy to just not bother with the things I don't care about. I get that a lot specifics on how things are done changed, but you can still play it as a game where you build stuff + monsters.

body:
I kinda agree that the direction they're going with new, overcomplicated mobs is really not a good one. New types of wood and stone are the sort of thing that make a massive difference, even the idea of revamping the Nether was pretty good compared to... bees?!

However, what's amazing is that you're able to roll back to almost any past update and play with whatever features you fancy.
body_html:
I kinda agree that the direction they're going with new, overcomplicated mobs is really not a good one. New types of wood and stone are the sort of thing that make a massive difference, even the idea of revamping the Nether was pretty good compared to... bees?!

However, what's amazing is that you're able to roll back to almost any past update and play with whatever features you fancy.

parent.body: What do you miss being able to do that you can't now? 1.7 beta is about where I got into it, so maybe some nostalgia for older versions is lost on me, but what I loved about having a little world where I build my things and explore is still there, except with more materials to choose from, more places to explore and different mobs to make it interesting. I agree that not all updates were good or focused on the right thing - I didn't like the direction the texture pack took either, the underground is in a sorry state and even terrain generation could really have been made more interesting by now, but generally I found it pretty easy to just not bother with the things I don't care about. I get that a lot specifics on how things are done changed, but you can still play it as a game where you build stuff + monsters.

body: Those *animations* are what hurt me the most. It's bad enough Bedrock Edition has emotes [citation needed], but now Java Edition is going down the hyperanimated path. It's losing me.
body_html: Those animations are what hurt me the most. It's bad enough Bedrock Edition has emotes [citation needed], but now Java Edition is going down the hyperanimated path. It's losing me.

body: But there's so much focus on survival and fantasy stuff now that blocks are more of a secondary thing. Rarely are any new blocks added that are useful for building, while non-optional "features" keep getting added which get in the way of building things, and in the case of survival mode, force you to play a certain way leaving little time for doing anything other than survival and power.
body_html: But there's so much focus on survival and fantasy stuff now that blocks are more of a secondary thing. Rarely are any new blocks added that are useful for building, while non-optional "features" keep getting added which get in the way of building things, and in the case of survival mode, force you to play a certain way leaving little time for doing anything other than survival and power.

parent.body: It doesn't take very long to do all the important and optional things in the game, and even so the old stuff is still there. If someone wants to focus on making awesome builds in a survival world they can. Nothings is going to stop them.
parent.body_html: It doesn't take very long to do all the important and optional things in the game, and even so the old stuff is still there. If someone wants to focus on making awesome builds in a survival world they can. Nothings is going to stop them.

body:
The only necessary thing to do is to get iron armor after that you can do whatever you like. Ocean Monuments, Woodland Mansions, the Nether, and the End are all optional. All the other stuff aside from certain biomes and a few structures are easy to find, and even then they are still optional to look for. If building is your main goal the distractions are still the same as they were several versions ago Spiders, Zombies, Creepers, Skeletons, and the occasional Enderman and Witch. The only place where there are more distractions would be the Nether and if you want the traditional blocks found there it won't take long to get them.
I understand that the game is a lot more different with all the new mobs and biomes, but the building aspect, the methods to obtain traditional blocks, and distractions haven't changed.
body_html: The only necessary thing to do is to get iron armor after that you can do whatever you like. Ocean Monuments, Woodland Mansions, the Nether, and the End are all optional. All the other stuff aside from certain biomes and a few structures are easy to find, and even then they are still optional to look for. If building is your main goal the distractions are still the same as they were several versions ago Spiders, Zombies, Creepers, Skeletons, and the occasional Enderman and Witch. The only place where there are more distractions would be the Nether and if you want the traditional blocks found there it won't take long to get them. I understand that the game is a lot more different with all the new mobs and biomes, but the building aspect, the methods to obtain traditional blocks, and distractions haven't changed.
